Windows 8 will support system-on-a-chip architectures using ARM processors. Unlike the x86 architecture that today's Windows laptops and desktops work with, ARM-based chips tend to run such low-power devices as tablets and smartphones. Steve Ballmer said, This announcement is really all about enabling a new class of hardware, and new silicon partners for Windows, to bring the widest possible range of form factors to the market. There has also been talk of tension between Eric Schmidt and Larry Page on competing priorities, Seth Harris added, with Eric Schmidt emphasizing the need to protect margins and Larry Page pushing for more innovation. Google has to do both but is losing talent and facing tough competition, so the balance is tough to reach, he concluded.
